I'll be talking about it in a slightly different way this topics on creating digital content sharing it online and
participating in basically any sort of online social computing space this is
how we connect with other people how we express ourselves show humor show attachment to other people and maintain
relationships and today we're going to talk about this all through the lens of aging what it means to be an older adult
and participate in these sorts of spaces so to help you understand why this problem space is important and
interesting I'll start with a quick story so this is Ethel Ethel is 105 years old so at 105 you would imagine
she has sort of normal age-related memory loss so she forgets people's names or her relationships to them and
she's becoming somewhat socially withdrawn so her daughter Alice is often looking for opportunities to engage her
mother in social interaction her daughter Alice knows how important it is to keep her mother engaged and
stimulated but her mother won't touch an iPad or anything else that looks like technology so now consider John over
here John has the early stages of dementia John at one time though however
he's a he's an active computer user one time he ordered order after order of the same exact item and these boxes kept
arriving at the house John was also on Facebook and John's posting things like I'm headed out of town for two weeks I'm
headed off to the bank as well right so things that shouldn't really be posted online now John and Alice are married so
Alice sees what's happening with her husband and also the situation with her mother Alice is pretty tech savvy as an
older adult she has over a dozen online accounts for her banking information health social connections so at this
point in time you know she doesn't want to hand over power of attorney like her husband has had to do to her so she asks
her children who are also in their 60s in older adults to just check on her from time to time the best we can do
right now is she says here are my login credentials for my bank account just kind of peek at my files and make sure
everything looks squared away go time to I'm look at my facebook feed and my Facebook profile make sure I'm not
connecting with any sort of unsavory folks um so this is really complex right
and then Alice's children also have their own desires they want to connect
with their grandmother and their father but their grandmother doesn't use the same sorts of platforms that they use
and their grant and their father often doesn't remember them or his relationship to them so in today's talk
I'm going to introduce several systems that help us think about what it means to design for staying active and engaged
online throughout the lifespan so as I started allude to it this is a really
important topic for many reasons one is that as we get older our social networks tend to shrink but there's also this
very clearly established relationship between having late-life social support and having positive physical and mental
health outcomes then the flip side of that is that social isolation can be associated with higher rates of
disability slower recovery from illness and even early death so it's really important that we think about ways of
helping people maintain their active social lives throughout the lifespan now
the good news is that recent analyses show that if you're active online as an
older adult you're less likely to feel depressed social Eisley socially isolated or lonely again some bad news
back in 2014 still 41% of older adults this is people in the u.s. 65 and older based on the
Pew Research data we're still offline now this gap is closing some but there are a significant portion of older
adults in the US who are still offline one of the contributing factors to being
offline is disability and so as we know as we age it becomes a very complex experience with changing values changing
experiences and needs but also changing abilities so if you think of even the youngest cohort of older adults and this
is US census data even people 65 to 69 one in four has a severe communicative
cognitive or physical disability couple that with the striking report from the
Alzheimer's Association one in three people is expected to least of older individuals passing away
with dementia or Alzheimer's disease this is very pervasive when we think about age-related disability so this is
the topic for our conversation today now in HCI though we tend to start you know
we think about this as a way of solving problems of Aging so we think about
technology as helping people remember medications or preventing wandering behavior now these are important issues
but they're only one aspect of the experience of what it means to get older what about creativity what about social
longing forming new relationships new partnerships these aspects really aren't often examined within the literature
it's much more as computer scientists we're often comfortable with identifying a problem and then knowing when we've
arrived at a very clear solution to some sort of aging related problem so this is
part of my theoretical framing and it draws from the field of critical gerontology that sort of destabilizes
these narratives around what it means to be an older person a couple of that with
my view of cognition so typically we
approach cognition from an information processing theoretical within an individual's head and instead
when we're dealing with individuals with cognitive impairment that puts the burden on that individual as lacking as
having a deficit but instead if we start to view cognition as distributed across
people time space and even our cultural practices that changes fundamentally how we approach system design and how we
study our technologies in the field so instead of studying the individual and perhaps a cognitive impairment located
within that person we can study an intelligent system of activity a caregiver working alongside an
individual with a cognitive impairment we can study the system of activity that includes technology we can start looking
at cognition as an emergent property of interaction so cognition is happening it's there it's there for us to study
it's not what's missing within an individual and we can also start thinking about the role that technology
can play in this process of meaning making so again I'll be talking a lot about this and system of dyads working in co-located
spaces and health technology can fit into that have we seen anyone study how
much someone tends to start distributing their their cognition as they start to age so you know things that I used to
try to keep in my own head all the time I still do we is there some curve where we see like people start to you know
post-it notes on places but for minor things in the environment or ask others to help with them and do we know like
what that actually looks like absolutely there's a whole line of work that's starting to think about that using
distributed cognition as one theoretical lens we could talk about it later if you want during the discussion but
absolutely I think that's an important part of us understanding what it means to live with a cognitive impairment and
my my view of a cognitive impairment is that we all have them at various times in our life right it could be medication
induced it could be stress I've had three kids after I have a baby I definitely have a different level of
cognitive functioning than I do at other times and so we think about cognitive impairment as working throughout all of
our lives not just as a particular condition that an older person might have um okay so just to tell you a
little bit about Who I am and what I do so I'm primarily a qualitative researcher I start out by going to the
field I work in therapy clinics retirement communities schools nursing
homes and I start by doing in-depth observations and interviews with a variety of stakeholders from there we
start to design new sorts of prototypes that help us understand things so these prototypes generally will we'll think
about testing them for initial accessibility and appeal but then we put them back out into the field with our
field partners for weeks months and even years at a time and here we're really
looking for things like changing communication practices as someone now adopted this technology over time in a
way that previously they hadn't are people more motivated to interact and to communicate socially are people
communicating or interacting in a way that's now more independent than they previously did and then with that with
these long term understandings of these systems in the field we can start to contribute back to our fundamental theories of human social behavior and
our practices with technology so to say it very simply I'm an ethnographer qualitative
researcher who builds systems as a way of understanding phenomena in the world so today I'll show you or I'll share
with you just a couple of these different systems and these different contexts of study the first one involves
the woman you met in the introduction this is Ethel and this study is about audio enhanced paper photos this work
was done a couple years ago but I still think it's relevant to our discussion today this is a case study that focuses
on Ethel's last year of life so we started out by doing observations and
interviews with Ethel's family now this is the wall in her room okay this is pretty characteristic of a lot of the
older individuals that we work with having lots of printed family photos displayed around to share with other
people we found out that these are particularly important as a way for Alice Ethel's daughter to engage her in
conversation so Alice says I come into Ethel's room say a few things and she
doesn't really interact in the conversation but if you start talking about who someone is in a foot in a
picture and do you remember that person it gives a focal point for communicating so we're thinking about in the early
stages of this project building on this practice of sharing paper photos and so within the field of HCI there's a long
history of enhancing physical objects and printed materials with audio or
sounds at the moment and so the work today will build on this long history but at the time of this study there
really wasn't anything available for an end user a non-technical end-user to create their own interactive paper
documents on the fly and so we created the tap and play system to address this and this system allows the user with
this is a commercial Livescribe pen with dot pattern paper to sketch out an interface and program it and say when
someone taps on this region I want it to play this particular message or I want it to recognize handwriting so the
system works like this so it recognizes any sort of user-defined polygon on
interactive dot patterned paper then using this custom control panel so this is the authoring interface is the pen
paper and this custom control panel over there you can decide whether the region plays audio
or recognizing handwriting you can decide what sort of interaction should
make this execute so this is important these look very basic it can recognize more complex gestures but the difference
between a pen down and a single tap gesture is huge for this population we found time and time again for a lot of
the older adults we're working with when they touch the pen to the paper they expected the magic to happen right and so being able to author at that level
was pretty important but then you can also do other things with these regions so you can associate this with a word in
a lexicon to say Reckitt when when someone writes something in here recognize these particular key words or do whatever was saved over in this so it
concert' in this region it can save as a pointer to another region so all this is encapsulated in the idea of a region
stored on the pin and then written out in XML so you can exchange these
customized activities between pens so this happened place system we developed over a two-year time period it began
with an early ethnographic study of speech language therapists using printed
materials as part of rehabilitation for adults who'd had a stroke and needed to relearn to speak and regain language and
what we saw here was that they had many ideas for for enhancing these paper documents but weren't able to do this on
their own and so we created a first version of this system deployed it in the field some things needed to be
improved so we continued to iterate and finally the tap and play system that I shared with you we deployed with over
100 people in four different contexts and today the study with Ethel's family
is just one of those so when we gave them these materials they created an interactive audio enhanced photo album
for Ethel so here you can see interaction across five generations of her family so children were able to
easily walk up and add songs or their own stories to Ethel's book this photo
album became this evolving family artifact so this is one of Ethel daughters and she is recording a message

very evocative for her as the daughter who's going back and revisiting these photos so what's nice about this is here

and so we started to see a few design conventions emerge people in this family

improvements this is based on survey data from her Ethel's family members and

then the other daughters also saying things like this process of revisiting these family photos is helping her

we can say it's successful because of these because of a couple reasons one as I mentioned any sort of engagement we're
seeing when the norm is really withdrawal in isolation especially in the last year of your life Ethel was
quite socially withdrawn and and didn't really want to interact with anybody before bringing this sort of technology
into her life and so we saw some improvements and that was really exciting and encouraging even for an in
of one case study but this is really a case of this older adult family group
collectively authoring these materials and I'd argue that this photo album in
the the the digital pen system we created was at just the right level of abstraction they were able to do what
they wanted to do in an efficient and clear manner with it and not much more but it also really drew on their
existing photo sharing practices which is quite important right they weren't asked to shift their practices to

it back she said I've also tried to show her photos on an iPad and she says no put them in the book I don't want anything
to do with that so for this particular centenarian this sort of hybrid media really worked well okay so moving from
that particular case study where Ethel was involved but she was not front and center in the
creation process now I'm going to describe some work from the context of art therapy involving older adults with
dementia where these individuals are definitely front and center in the creation and sharing process we're going
to talk about what that means for thinking about sharing and participating
in online social environments through therapeutic artwork okay so dementia is
marked by a significant decline in cognitive ability that affects your language and your memory it can be a
very isolating experience as well linked with anxiety depression in
society really tends to view dementia when you think about dementia you don't have a warm fuzzy about it right when
I'm talking about this it's not an exciting topic you guys are here last class of this mint or a quarter thank you for doing that dementia is not an
exciting topic but hopefully today it will be and so what we're gonna do is
think about this typical positioning of people with dementia in our society and we're gonna turn it on its head we're
gonna study the context of art therapy and so we've been working art therapy for over two years now and also
interviewing a variety of art therapists in addition to our observations art therapy is all about self-expression
it's a way of when a person does not have words maybe not the ability or the
desire to produce language they can create art as a way of expressing their desires and their needs and their own
experience with disability so art therapy is about providing people with a sense of dignity wherein the rest of
your life you may not be able to choose what you wear what you eat or where you go but in art therapy it's all about
empowering people as creators and as competent and engaged individuals so
what's special about art therapy and I'd argue the arts more broadly is this this
is a quote from our therapist one of the one of the main people we've worked with she says when you're having a creative interaction with somebody you're not
bound by the normal linear conversation and socially acceptable rules of what's appropriate you don't even
necessarily have to be able to speak coherently to be able to express yourself creatively right so when we
think about the social rules we have that prize logic and reasoning those are
far less important in the arts things like your sensory experience humor emotional awareness and creativity are
all valued and those are all continuing strengths of people with dementia but
making and sharing artwork in this context depends on the facilitating role of the art therapists remember I said
I'd come back to this intelligent unit of interaction between a therapist and a person with dementia or cognitive
impairment and here's where we really see this this work happening in a deeper
way so the therapists hone what they call their third hand okay so the third
hand is this is written by a famous art therapist edith kramer she says it helps
the creative process along without being intrusive without distorting the meaning or imposing your own ideas and
preferences on the client you use your artistic competence and imagination in empathetic service of other people right
so the therapist is there their job is to be the third the third
hand like machinery make the physical work happen so this is a woman with Parkinson's disease and she's trying to
line up a particular piece of paper on her her art project right here and so the therapist comes in at the right
moment and helps her accomplish this and what the therapist says when we asked her about this it was always her process
I was the extra hand that's what a therapist should be doing by second nature this is a very
empowering process especially as I mentioned compared to other aspects of daily life and really seeing art work in
this way is a conceptual shift and we've written about this in a recent or an upcoming KY paper it shifts from viewing
dementia as an impairment and it's all about a deficit and a loss to thinking
about people's behaviors as expressions of who they are now this particular woman right here she
had a stroke and so she has some limited range of motion she she cannot speak fluently and she has some limited range
of motion in her arm but what she does is often grabs a paintbrush and does this rhythmic motion and so the therapist introduced
art materials to take advantage of this and now what was usually seen as a
negative symptom of a disease is an expression of the self and so they're not painting on you know construction
paper with Crayolas they have fine art materials so this is a silk scarf that this woman created and it's her
signature style this style has emerged over time as she's been in art therapy and I can tell you this family has vied
over her artwork they're actually fighting over who gets her artwork it's become a prized possession so now you
take a person who really is questioning their role in society and their value and what they can contribute and you put
them in a position where they're the one who's able to gift and to to show that
they're contributing back to their own family okay so some of you may not care
about art therapy or older adults are aging in general so let me try to give you a few reasons why I think this

what is that we can start to look at the health benefits we can actually look at some outcomes of staying socially

protected health information so artwork serves as both an expressive artifact

also worked quite well so taking these insights together we created the moment

with cognitive impairments so we wanted to understand what they're doing in
terms of managing online life for their care recipients so we heard stories like this you know this woman saying my

husband go online because it is so important to his quality of life and who he is as a person right so to me that's

people to be active and engaged online so in terms of caregivers we know a lot
about the physical emotional and social stress of caregiving it's an intense
burden and so we've started designing technologies in HCI that can solve
problems around like remote caregiving now you don't have to go over to a place to check on a loved one you can sort of
check remotely but there's not a lot out there that says what are caregivers doing to support the online lives of
their care recipients so that's what we're studying here what we found through our participants is that
caregivers describe their support very much like the third hand is coming and going trying to fade into the background
when they were not needed so one person said it's like a roller coaster it's up
and down it's a vicious cycle and it's not just going down and staying down he'll go down then I'll come back up a
little so they don't want to restrict them in some way as people are sort of coming and going and in terms of their
abilities so we identified four forms of work that caregivers were doing today
I'll just present two of those the first form of work caregivers are performing is connecting so they're doing a lot to
make their care recipient feel that they're connected in their online world so one thing and one reason for this is
just like with ethel and her photo album they have a belief that visiting sites like facebook and looking at people in
your network is actually beneficial that that's actually going to help in the long run people remember who is in their
network and remember those social relationships but they're also doing things like posting on behalf of their
care recipient you know one person said i'll post pictures i'll say daddy went outside today or daddy was able to dress
himself so they're trying to post things that are positive and showing that this person is still active and engaged and making the rest of their network aware
of their life experience but at times this can really conflict so sometimes family members will post
inappropriate things like daddy was in diapers right and the caregivers and the family members sort of get in fights and
go back and forth about what's the appropriate level of disclosure especially when our goal is to make sure this person feels connected and involved
in our little online world now the second form of work that caregivers do
is what we call protecting so caregivers are regularly going through in filtering
and removing distressing content from the news feeds of their care recipients they do this through really really
inefficient strategies they may share account credentials right and so they go in so that they have a single account
that they're using and the caregiver goes through and make sure there's nothing distressing like for example one individual encountered the same story of
a train wreck four or five different times and every time they would read the article they would become distressed and
anxious and their caregiver would need to come to them and calm them down they'd go away forget they had that

about disasters as a family we have to get together and start raining in the content that these that that are Karaca
pants seeing so they're developing these workarounds like I said sharing passwords or even setting up email
filters one thing that really surprised
me too is that they're going through the person's network and they're deleting and defriending people who may be doing
things that they consider inappropriate caregivers were really divided on this some said yeah it's my job to make sure
there's no one in their network doing these things others said no it's not really my job these were his friends
before his accident or before the onset of dementia so I'm just gonna let him you know interact with them I'll do
damage control and deal with it after the fact so what's really clear here is
that caregivers lack the sorts of mechanisms and tools to do the types of
filtering and protecting work that they desire and do that in a way that's still empowering of their care recipient okay
